job_title: Senior Officer in Bradford, South West England, England

job_title: Lecturer in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Gives an opportunity to start career in academia if no prior experience.
cons: Almost all staff members in positions of seniority (in department of health studies) have no leadership qualities. Zero transparency about how and why decisions are made, very much top down approach, very inexperienced staff in these positions make for a very disorganised department where things often go wrong and no one accepts responsibility rather blame each other. This makes for an extremely ‘toxic’ environment. Staff members who are good at their jobs are rewarded for this by being given more work, the work of other staff members who don’t do their own. This puts more pressure on staff and contributes to stress and low morale. The senior staff refuse to acknowledge any problems and seem to place the blame for poor management decisions back on staff who have no say in the making of these decisions. All in all an extremely negative and challenging place to work with no support where serious concerns are ignored month on month.

job_title: Admissions in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England

job_title: Administrative Officer in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England

review_title: Overall a nice place to work depending on job
job_title: Programmer Administrator in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros:
People are friendly and generally supportive.
The work is varied.
cons:
You do not get paid enough for the amount of work required - pay is very poor compared to similar roles at other universities. 
The turnover for Programme Administration is high so team numbers are often down so other administrators have to to make up for people who have left, on sick leave etc. Some teams have colleagues who perform poorly/are incompetent but the HR processes are pretty rubbish because no one can be bothered to do what it takes to take them through the relevant process, as a result, they are allowed to stay on after probation even though they cannot do the job.
Academics regularly miss important deadlines which means programme administrators are often put in challenging situations to meet their own deadlines but senior management don't do anything about it.
Since the restructure, programme administrators have become responsible for extra duties but also as the front facing team for students, often have to also answer student queries for other departments who do not have to speak to students directly so you end up also trying to resolve queries related to other areas too.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Nice people to work with.
cons:
The admin is broken - processes are inefficient and result in incorrect outputs, that then require checking and fixing manually. 

The workload model is inaccurate, incorrectly implemented and vastly underestimates how long a task will take (or doesn't include a lot of the tasks in the first place). This means academics work way beyond their hours (even compared to other institutions)

job_title: Programmer Administrator in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Flexible working, great supportive team and colleagues, great holiday leave.
cons:
Pay is not brilliant, time pressures at times of exam boards and assessment committees and having to take on a heavier workload. 

Work can be boring, repetitive and not much opportunity to develop skills or do courses/training that is in line with career goals e.g. I would like to do project management but there are no certification and training courses available for this (unless you're already doing this as a job and it's relevant to your work responsibilities).

job_title: IT in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: The amount of annual leave
cons: The culture throughout this organisation is toxic, in the couple of years I was here, I was never made to feel welcome. The disjointed executive leadership team ensure a parent child culture exist resulting in very low morale across all areas. You should really consider if you can tolerate this environment if you are considering working here because it’s not a strategic thinking organisation therefore, it’s not about what you can bring to the organisation, it’s about what you are given permission to do, which won’t be anything groundbreaking.
